intro: Campium parvum, commonly known as the small campion, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, which includes other familiar plants like carnations and poppies. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters, featuring slender stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are pink to purple, with five petals and a distinctive central column, blooming from late spring to early autumn. Campium parvum is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and disturbed soils, and it is known for its delicate appearance and ecological importance.
